title: Why are old horror movies better than the ones nowadays? - Quora

response.answer_text: You mean legendary titles like “Night of the Lepus,” “The Killer Shrews,” or “King of the Zombies?” Oh yes, titles from before the 1990’s(an arbitrary cutoff based on my age) were exclusively superior to the ones today. In fact I’m still on the hunt for “Critters” and “Killdozer” on blue-ray. Even the worst of the horror movies of the Before Times are masterpieces as opposed to trash like “Get Out,” “Happy Death Day,” and “The Babadook.” Perhaps it’s the inability for these millennials to understand just what’s actually scary. Or maybe new moviemakers are too quick to blat you in the head with jump scares to bother pacing their work properly like the great Ed Wood or the team behind “Manos: Hands of Fate.” Perhaps it’s color film making it impossible to pass chocolate syrup as blood. Could it be the shift to digital photography and effects that has ruined the sense of immersion of the audience as opposed to the masterful practical work done in “From Hell it Came?” Apologies for the sarcasm up to this point, but I get annoyed by both sides of this argument. On the one hand, many of my favorite films are of the older schools of filmmaking (“Forbidden Planet,” “The Thing,” etc.) and are better for how the limitation of the medium shapes the final product, but on the other, I absolutely hate people who refuse to watch or play something just because it’s older. A more direct answer than the ones I’ve sarcastically listed above: there are more good old movies than good new movies because there are more old movies period, and even then the good/bad horror movie percentage is probably about the same. It’s just that the forgettable ones tend to end up forgotten, and must be sought after. If you do decide to seek the bad horror out, here’s a couple places to get started: Mystery Science Theater 3000 made bad movies fun by insulting them and asking you to join in. The original has all the oldies, but the reboot is worth a look too.10–50 movie collections, the cheaper the better. Usually these will have 10% uninterestingly competent films, and the rest is trash.Hit up your local thrift store: where bad movies go to die. Sometimes you might find an actual gem in there too to keep yourself motivated.Some film journalists and critics run series of articles dedicated to bad movies. A popular one is IHE’s “Search for the Worst,” but I found that Moviebob’s yearly “Schlocktober” series to be more concise and interesting.Have fun with your bad movies.
